Hey guys
I am implementing a filterable recyclerview. And I used this as an example.
<https://github.com/Wrdlbrnft/Searchable-RecyclerView-Demo>

attachments.title: Wrdlbrnft/Searchable-RecyclerView-Demo
attachments.text: Searchable-RecyclerView-Demo - An example app using a SearchView to filter items in a RecyclerView while taking full advantage of item animations!

text: Only problem here is, he used notifyItemRemoved etc to create feel of a searchable adapter.
Problem is I can’t implement a onItemClickListener anymore. Because recyclerview doesn’t represent any list anymore
Any1 know a solution for this?
It’s a list with ±500 items, so ability to filer is a must
<@U0K1ALDQE>: use onItemTouchListener
And what will that do for me? :smile:
I can’t get a value, because position mismatches
I have a custom onItemClickListener that passes me the position
Oh
What position?
Position on screen?
Apparently not, it’s acting up.
There must be something in that library
It’s not a library
What it does is that it uses notifyItemRemoved, notifyItemInserted. Which has the effect of removing it in the recyclerview but the list is unaffected
So why my list of 500 items remains. I can filter down to 4
So that adapter still has all of the values but just doesn't show them?
Exactly
I would implement a method to get the lists too
I'm not looking at the code
But I would guess it gets the itemCount based on the search
Somewhere in memory there is that list
You just need to save it somewhere for a longer period
Yeah, but I don’t think you can reach it
You can always reach it
What happens with notifyItemRemoved is that. the recyclerview hides that position without re iterating the is again
so basically when you have a list of 5 items
A,B,C,D,E
I see that it has an animateTo
Don't you need to put it in there?
Uh
It always calls remove, mode or addItem()
ExampleAdapter.mModels contains the models
So if you implement a listener it should act just like any other RecyclerView afaik
position mismatches for some reason
But for some reason the onBindViewHolder position mismatches if I go below a certain number of items still visible
Okay, that’s indeed the problem.
If size < items visible on screen. onBindViewHolder doesn’t get called anymore
I think it's better to implement an ItemTouchListener instead of always adding an onclicklistener per item
Try using addOnItemTouchListener to add one to the RecyclerView
Then log the position
Yeah this isn’t working
positions are messed up. Never had any problems with it like this before.
Thanks <@U061HDV96>. I’ll let you know in a sec if it works :simple_smile:
I have a custom adapter for sections
I can't remember off the top of my head, but I'm not sure whether it gives you the position on screen or position in the list
There is a way to convert it
I have a SectionOnClickListener
<@U0K1ALDQE>:  how about passing an item ID/hash instead of position?
Because I can’t reach the correct item within the recyclerview
if I don’t have the correct position there is no way for me to get the correct position
Ow wait. Unless, I attach the listener in the ViewHolder ofc
>I think it's better to implement an ItemTouchListener instead of always adding an onclicklistener per item
If you log it, you should see some positions that make sense
I tried and I know where the problem comes from
How bad practice is it to attach a listener in the viewholder?
<http://sapandiwakar.in/recycler-view-item-click-handler/>

attachments.title: Recycler View Item Click Listener
attachments.text: With the Android L release, RecyclerView has replaced ListView as the goto component for creating a view for providing window to a large data set. It promises lots of performance improvements over the standard list view. To use the RecyclerView...
attachments.fallback: Sapan Diwakar: Recycler View Item Click Listener

text: lol nvm that
Well I think if you add 500 listeners
I need more coffe -.- lol <@U0548MM6B> what you said should work
It'll take a hit on performance
<@U061HDV96>: it’s only 1 listener but binded to multiple items
haha :smile:
I've always used a customised OnTouchListener
Okay, thanks <@U0548MM6B> you solved the problen
lol pass item instead of position ><
`mListener.onItemClick(childView, view.getChildAdapterPosition(childView));`
I def need more coffee been up working since 6
Yeah, that would’ve solved it 2 <@U061HDV96>
Both thanks for the input! I might consider your solution.
Since then I won’t have to pass a listener to my adapter.
Ya, listeners is something I'd keep out of an Adapter
Looks sloppy I feel it’s not his responsibility to listener for something
I still have to figure out how to get the correct position from OnItemTouchListener though
You create a custom listener <@U061HDV96>?
Mind passing me an example?
I can take a quick look at
The link I sent showcases an ItemClickListener
Ow oops
Thanks :+1:

text: <@U0LTW45PS|scolirly_advent> has joined the channel
Any1 know a good / clean solution to hide a view when keyboard is shown?
<@U0K1ALDQE|simon.vergauwen> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/simon.vergauwen/F0LTX3PSM/-.txt|Untitled>

I thought I could add some custom (CoordinatorLayout) behavior to the ImageView to hide it when the keyboard pops up. But I’m not quite sure how to catch that in CoordinatorLayout. Some suggested that when change is bigger than x pixels it’s most likely the keyboard. Or when edittext loses focus. But both solutions are hacks.
with adjustResize everything is visible, but the ImageView is like 80dp high so pretty worthless for me.
Is it necessary to authenticate with backend server after google sign in? What are the advantages or should I say the security concerns if I don;t do authentication?
What backend server? Your own?
Yes
for API calls.
Basically this step - <https://developers.google.com/identity/sign-in/android/backend-auth>
<@U0K1ALDQE>: Keyboard stuff is a mess in android, you don’t have any way of knowing it is there apart from the hacks you mentioned. There are no events to listen for
<@U0ESBKWKA>: of course you want to verify them, otherwise someone can just spam you tokens and until you accept one and thus log in as a different user
<@U04TK850N>: I knew it was a mess but that’s insane ><I’ll figure something out. (Spend a shitload of time on this and give up)
I used that window size change hack before and it worked in my limited tests. the app never went into production so ymmv
I’m currently making a lib / demo for a costumer. So I don’t want to use any hacks :smile:
Write your own keyboard :smile:
haha
:no_mouth: :gun:
this lib uses the height change method too: <https://github.com/yshrsmz/KeyboardVisibilityEvent>

attachments.title: yshrsmz/KeyboardVisibilityEvent
attachments.text: KeyboardVisibilityEvent - Android Library to handle soft keyboard visibility change event.
